alt_statements.statement: University administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, while drawing a clear line at harassment, threats, or targeting people because they’re Jewish, Muslim, Arab, or Palestinian. They should create structured spaces—forums, teach-ins, mediated dialogues—where people can actually learn the history and hear each other instead of just shouting across barricades. As someone who cares about justice and comes from a place shaped by colonialism and U.S. power, I think it’s crucial that students can call out state violence and oppression without being silenced or punished for their politics. At the same time, administrators should prioritize students’ safety, mental health, and ability to attend class without intimidation, and be transparent about any security measures they take.

As someone who values order and personal responsibility, I think university administrators should allow peaceful demonstrations about Israel and Gaza, but set very clear rules and enforce them consistently so that classes, safety, and other students’ rights aren’t disrupted. Free speech is important, but it doesn’t justify harassment, vandalism, or shutting down the campus, and administrators should not take sides politically—only uphold the law, protect students, and maintain an environment where people can study and work.

University administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and express solidarity with Palestinians and Israelis, while drawing a firm line against harassment, hate speech, and any form of violence. As someone who cares deeply about justice and equality, I believe campuses should create structured forums for dialogue, teach historical context, and ensure that vulnerable communities feel safe. Instead of resorting quickly to police or punitive measures, administrators should prioritize de-escalation, mediation, and clear, consistently applied policies that respect both free expression and the dignity of everyone on campus.

As an old woman who has seen war and loss in Vietnam, I believe university leaders must keep their campuses peaceful and safe first, while still allowing students to speak their minds respectfully. Demonstrations should be carefully supervised so they do not turn into threats, hatred, or violence against any group, and there should be clear rules everyone must follow. Schools should encourage calm dialogue, prayer, and learning about the conflict, not shouting and chaos.

I’m only 12, so I don’t totally get everything about Israel and Gaza, but I think campus leaders should make sure people can speak up peacefully without anyone getting hurt or bullied. They should have clear rules that apply the same to everyone, and step in fast if protests turn threatening or scary so students feel safe going to class. If I was there, I’d want a place where people could share their stories and listen to each other instead of just yelling.

As a Jewish medical research scientist, I care deeply about both free inquiry and the safety and dignity of everyone on campus. University administrators should protect robust, even passionate, political expression about Israel and Gaza while drawing a clear, consistently enforced line against harassment, dehumanizing rhetoric, and disruptions that shut down teaching or research. They should respond with transparent policies grounded in evidence, civil rights law, and data on campus safety—not political pressure—while investing in facilitated dialogue and support services for students most directly affected.

As someone who’s really into activism and plans to go to college soon, I think university administrators need to protect students’ right to protest on Israel/Gaza while also making sure everyone feels physically safe and not targeted because of their identity. They should set clear, content-neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, and then actually listen to student voices from all sides instead of just trying to shut things down when it gets uncomfortable. Administrators should also create more structured spaces—like forums or teach-ins—where people can learn the history and hear different perspectives so protests are backed by real understanding, not just slogans.

I don’t really understand everything about Israel and Gaza, but I know people are very sad and mad, and that makes me feel a little scared. I think the grown-ups in charge at the university should make sure no one is getting hurt or bullied, and that everyone is being kind while they talk about it. My church teaches me to care about people who are hurting, so I think they should help students listen to each other and make sure everyone feels safe.

As someone who values free expression and leans liberal, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to protest peacefully on all sides of the Israel/Gaza issue, while drawing a very clear line at harassment, threats, or discrimination against any group. They should create structured, well-facilitated forums for dialogue and education—bringing in credible experts, historians, and community leaders—so the campus becomes a place where students can confront hard realities, learn, and argue passionately without feeling unsafe or silenced.

University administrators should protect free speech and peaceful protest, but they also have a duty to maintain order and ensure that no student feels threatened or harassed.
